title: R44447
content: The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) regulates campaign contributions in federal elections by defining contributions as money or anything of value given to influence an election. Contributions are distinguished from expenditures, which involve spending money directly for election advocacy. FECA regulates contributions through limits, source restrictions, and disclosure requirements, with specific limits on individual contributions periodically adjusted for inflation. The law prohibits contributions made in the name of another person to prevent circumvention of contribution limits. Federal campaign finance law prohibits contributions made in the name of another person to prevent circumvention of contribution limits. This provision aims to prevent individuals from giving money to someone else to contribute to the same candidate after reaching the maximum contribution limit. The law also prohibits corporations from reimbursing employees for campaign contributions and bans contributions from corporations and labor unions from their own funds. Candidates, however, are allowed to accept contributions from separate segregated funds or political action committees.
